title: What will be the annual rate of housing starts for April 2021?
possible_answers: More than 1.2 million but less than 1.4 million
preds: 1.7 million consensus, assuming a 8% standard deviation around that. https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/housing-starts

Since April 2020 the annual rate for housing starts has been trending upwards, with March 2021 reaching 1.739 million. If the figure continues to trend upward there is a good chance that the figure will be more than 1.6 million. However, from January to February of 2021 the annual rate dropped by around 0.2 million, so if another drop were to occur the figure could fall below 1.6 million. Generally speaking, it seems like April's annual rate will not drop but instead continue to trend upward.
A time-series forecast indicated values upwards of 1.6, but there is enough uncertainty to downplay the max outcome.

Another bullish indicator on the housing picture, tight supply and rising prices. That, plus the rate rise cooling off looks bullish for housing starts: https://www.google.com/search?q=march+housing+supply&oq=march+housing+supply&aqs=edge..69i57.3514j0j1&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8&safe=active&ssui=on
I saw a $100 plus tac sheet of 4x8 3/4. It was $25 w/tax a year ago/ If it does not hit 1.6 it will be supply shortages that do it.

Monthly drops are usually about 100 historically, and the sharpest drops have been 300 per month right as COVID hit, it's pretty unlikely that we'd go from the current  1,739 to below 1,400 without something pretty dramatic.  Sharp one month spikes of over 100 however are often followed by dips of around 10%. A 10% dip would put us back under 1.6M starts. However, the trend is overall upwards. Demand remains incredibly high and mortgage remain stable and low so far (https://www.nerdwallet.com/mortgages/mortgage-rates). Dips after spikes have been shallower when the trend has been upward. However, lumber supply remains severely limited and houses permitted but not started is trending sharply upward, so we may be bouncing around our maximum starts capacity as is, while the abundance of demand is resulting in permits for constructions that won't be started until materials prices ease a bit.  The buckets are a bit unfortunate here since my prediction would be centered a little under 1.6, since a 10% dip would put us at 1.565. Dips are smaller when the trend is upward (8% would be 1.6), but I lean a bit toward the normal 10% dip due to supply issues and the idea that we're probably near max capacity, or that any further growth won't be at the same rapid pace as recent trends. Neither outcome would be surprising.

I am significantly different from the crowd on this so I'm either going to get this question very wrong or very right. Home sales have been decreasing due to rising interest rates and rising home prices. I don't buy the idea that February was low because of bad weather. I'm a real estate appraiser in Oregon and we had power out for large areas of the state for about 6 days and it did not affect real estate sales. If people need to move due to their life circumstances and they can afford it they are going to move. Cold weather is not going to stop them.  April 10 the CPI is going to jump considerably, to above 2%, and this will affect mortgage rates. Also I think there was some pent-up demand from the lockdowns which stopped construction, and I think we have worked through that. Typically home construction does not start until a buyer is already in place. Developers learned their lesson in 2008 and rarely build without a buyer in place. They don't want to be caught with a bunch of inventory if the housing market shifts. So rising rates matter. I definitely don't see housing starts climbing above February levels with rising rates. https://www.zerohedge.com/personal-finance/pending-home-sales-crash-february-weather-rates-inventory-blamed

Too bullish on housing starts initially and ignored the system-level factors that seem to be having an effect. Two dips in a row is worrying considering the historical FRED data but not damning. One concern is a spike in mortgage rates if banks continue to be scared about inflation, leading to a decrease in demand (to the extent that it's currently driven by low interest rates), and raising capital costs for the very capital-intensive process of home-building, both of which may lead homebuilders to not start projects they otherwise would have. The Fed has been clear that it isn't worried about inflation but the market has disagreed, the Core PCE Price Index Data coming out this Friday will be pretty significant on that front. Rates are still at historic lows, but what a change in interest rates means for the future is what I'll be watching. The second concern is lumber prices which have continued to rise. It's not the sort of thing you can easily swap out in the building process, like you can't use the same permit for a building with a concrete frame instead of a wood one (in my understanding) so that shouldn't be something that can be worked around. It's added an estimated $24k in cost to an average new home, and median home prices were $340k, so it's a ~7% increase, meanwhile existing home sale prices have gone up by more that double that percentage (about 16%), so it's a negative but not a crippling one. Lastly, part of the supply crunch that has driven prices so high has been people not listing homes during the pandemic, which may or may not ease in the coming weeks in the US depending on whether we decide to be dumb and how the vaccine rollout goes. But housing starts have a longer time horizon, and builders may recognize that they've run out of time to start and complete projects to take advantage of the high prices from lack of inventory (but that's pure speculation).  Overall though, it's hard to see the past two months' declines as a new trend, considering builder confidence remains super high, permits are still very high (despite a February dip), and projects authorized but not started remain flat as well. The numbers we're predicting are seasonally adjusted but don't account for the exceptionally harsh winter we just had in many parts of the country, so the dip may simply be from weather.  Another kinda stupid possibility is that it's because February is a shorter month so there's fewer days to start construction. It's 8% shorter than the average month and January is longer, and if you adjust for that difference there's basically no change. April will be a shorter month though since its only 30 days, so that's also a slight bump to the lower volume buckets.

Updating from 1/6/15/36/42 [1] as the Feb 2021 number was 1.42M. As I had pointed out in [1], the crowd had been overenthusiastic about the top bucket (it was 90% at one point), so it's good to see people coming back down to earth. Always make sure you are forecasting, and not nowcasting! (I.e. extrapolating recent trends in too simple a manner.) There have been news pieces about how the Feb decrease is due to cold weather, and therefore we'll see an increase as it warms up in Mar-Apr, but, does anyone really know? The cold weather was there, yes, and HOUST went down, but that is not sufficient to establish causality, as everyone on GJOpen knows. My mental model is that building a house is a vastly complicated endeavor depending on dozens of factors, so it is hard or impossible to blame any single factor. Another consideration is that the cold weather may have lingering effects. I think I read that a housing unit counts as started when they first start digging the hole for the foundations. Well, whatever precedes the digging (leveling the plot of land? clearing it?), probably also less of that was done due to the cold weather. So we would still see fewer housing starts down the line even when it warms up. Also, remember that the FRED numbers are *seasonally adjusted*. That means that March-April don't have to be colder than February for HOUST to be low. They just have to have worse weather than the *average March-April* (to an extent that impedes construction). With all this in sight, I am moving almost all mass to the top 3 buckets, but I will remain somewhat agnostic about which will come true. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1237381

I found some interesting data today while looking at FRED information regarding new home starts.  It provides an interesting way to look at this program that I haven't heard previously discussed. The new data I hadn't previously considered is "builder applications for permits."  This number continues to rise from its previous low in April 2020.  Since October 2020, this number has been 1554, 1635, 1704, and 1886 (measured in thousands of units).  Clearly, builders are applying for permits to build new houses.   Taken in order of what a builder needs to start a new house, which is the ultimate question we're being asked to forecast.   1) Land to build on (somewhat constrained right now based on various news articles)
2) A permit (discussed above, rising fast)
3) Material to build the house (rising lumber costs, houses cost more, fewer people may buy houses, causing homebuilders to slow-building if they don't have buyers.  Or they just reduce their profit margin.)
4) Workers to build the house Somewhere in there is a customer to sell the home to.  Many companies will build new homes without a contracted purchaser.  Customers can come in at any point in the build process, so that isn't too important. So this really comes down to a competition between the rising cost of houses and builders' profit margins.  Permits are continuing to filed, so builders want to build houses.  I also think as mortgage rates start to rise, people are going to want to jump on the historic lows. As the economy starts to recover, I think the strong housing market will continue.  I'm going to bump my forecast up a bit based on the continued rise of permit applications.

The first step to forecasting a question is the understand the question!  In this case, there are three statistics that revolve around housing starts.  1) Building permits for new homes 2) Housing Starts 3) Housing Completions In December 2020, those numbers were 1,709,000 / 1,669,000  / and 1,417,000 respectively.  In this instance, we are talking about the actual housing starts. Doing some more base rate analysis with information provided by The U.S. Census Bureau and the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, privately-owned housing starts in December 2020 were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1,669,000. This is 5.8 percent (±11.0 percent) above the revised November estimate of 1,578,000 for December 2020 and is 5.2 percent (±10.1 percent) above the December 2019 rate of 1,587,000.  The 1.669 million number is consistent with what the St Louis Federal Reserve provides for December as well.  There is also a great graph that provides historical data going back 60 years!  https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/HOUST Using the graph provided by the FRED, new housing starts hit rock bottom in March 2009, which was the height of the Great Recession.  Since that time, housing starts have consistently risen, but it has not yet hit the all-time highs of January 2006. Looking back over the last 50 years, it seems like the median number (half the months above, half the months below is about 1.5 million.  Therefore, I think much more weight should be given above 1.4 million.  That is the OUTSIDE view.   Next, let's look at the unique instances of this case. Interests rates are historically low and I belive the FED will probably keep its benchmark less than 0.5%.  Lending will continue to be cheap.  Second, new home starts traditionally rise in the spring.  Weather conditions allow home construction to advance across the country.  Third. employment should continue to rise as the COVID vaccine gets rolled out.  Therefore, people will have jobs to back those loans.  As the number of available homes remains low, house prices will go up.  This will spark supply by builders, who think they have the opportunity to make money.  More houses will be made available by builders to take advantage of these high prices.  Another reason for the robust market is that Millennials are finally putting their money into homeownership. According to the U.S. Census Bureau, the homeownership rate for 25-to-34-year-olds rose to 40.7% by the end of last year.  This is significant because Millennials, the generation of people in their mid-20s to late-30s, currently surpasses Baby Boomers as the nation’s largest living adult generation. As the remaining percentage of this group starts investing in homes in the near future, demand will persist.  All of these factors indicate that the housing market is poised to remain strong as we head into the new year. And as Jonathan Woloshin, head of U.S. real estate at UBS Global Wealth Management, believes, they could “buoy the housing market for years to come.” Why might housing starts decline?  As COVID cases drop, maybe people will move back to the city and fill all those empty apartments and condos that are already built.  Maybe all the qualified candidates for new homes will already have loans and contracts, leaving people who are unable to obtain loans as the only candidates for new construction.  It's possible the new construction houses could be above their price point. With all that considered, my initial hunch is to go with 63% as more than 1.6 million, 32% between  1.4 million and 1.6 million, and just 5% with 1.2-1.4 million.  But before I make my forecast, let's check the wisdom of the crowd.... The current crowd consensus is 53%, 46%, and 1% for those same categories.  Given that, I'll adjust ever so slightly to get closer to those numbers. I also took a look at the comments provided by others and the only thing I found that didn't consider was the cost of labor and supplies (thanks to @MCJNDU).  I don't see that changing much through April.  A major forest fire could cause timber prices to rise, and trade wars could cause steel to rise (girders, etc), but both of those seem unlikely.

Base Rate:  Using regression analysis of the last 10 years of FRED housing start data, we should expect April 2021 housing starts to be 1,497,756.  From Excel, the formula for new housing starts is: Y= 6.6816X + 655.87 Where Y is monthly new housing starts and X is the number of months since January 2011 (for April 2021, X = 126).  Inside View Adjustments:  Industry analysts suggests new housing starts depend on many variables, three of the most significant are demographics, interest rates, and general health of the economy.  However, examination of each variable suggests negligible impact on the base rate.  Demographics: I don’t see any reason to adjust the base rate for demographic shifts occurring in the next four months. Anecdotal evidence suggests the COIVD pandemic has encouraged mass migration out of urban centers, which would cause a spike in new housing starts.  However, empirical research does not support this assertion (reference Forbes article below). Interest Rates:  Interest rates are unlikely to change in the next four months.  On 27 January 2021, the FED announced its intention to keep the Federal Funds Rate at its current target of 0% to 0.25%.  The FED Chairman stated he “wanted to see substantial further progress toward our [economic] goals before we modify our asset purchase guidance.” General Economic Health:  Independent of interest rates, general economic health is a significant variable affecting new housing starts.  Key indicators like new unemployment insurance applications and GDP growth suggest the partial economic recovery that occurred between August 2020 and December 2020 is slowing down.  While new housing starts rose significantly above average from August to December, the recent economic slow-down will likely return this rate closer to average growth.  This trend actually re-enforces movement back to the base rate of 1.49M.

BASE RATES
The base rate since 1 Jan 1959 (first date available) is 13/13/18/25/31. The base rate from Dec 1990 to Nov 2020 (30y, length of a mortgage) is 21/17/19/20/23. This makes sense; the 30y period starts literally at the bottom of the 1990 dip, and includes the unprecedented crisis of 2006-2009. So it's lower than the overall average. INSIDE VIEW
Looking at the graph [1] It's hard not to see a kind of cyclic nature to it. And except for the pandemic, we seemed to be in the increasing part of the cycle in 2020. We're at 1.55M in Nov 2020. So we should skew higher than the average. I don't understand why the crowd is giving the top bucket only 1%. I don't understand interest rates 100% but here is my best guess. Low interest rates means it's cheaper for builders to borrow money to build. It also means that builders will capture more of the final home price than before. Roughly speaking, people have a fixed budget, say $1M, to buy a house. (It amounts to the same if we phrase that as a max monthly payment.) With high interest rates, that money could go $500k towards the actual house, and $500k towards interest. But with low interest rates, the split could be $900k house, $100k interest. Therefore, builders are incentivized to build more, both on the input side (cheaper capital) and on the output side (more profits). As builders realize this, I expect more building to get done in the near term. Still, I don't know anything about houses or building them, so I won't deviate from the historical average too much. "Use of seasonally adjusted time series data can be misleading because a seasonally adjusted series contains both the trend-cycle component and the error component. As such, what appear to be "downturns" or "upturns" may actually be randomness in the data. For this reason, if the purpose is finding turning points in a series, using the trend-cycle component is recommended rather than the seasonally adjusted data."
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seasonal_adjustment#Shortcomings_of_using_seasonally_adjusted_data ___ Q5: "What kinds of seasonal effects are removed during seasonal adjustment? Seasonal adjustment procedures for monthly time series estimate effects that occur in the same calendar month with similar magnitude and direction from year to year. In series whose seasonal effects come primarily from weather (rather than from, say, Christmas sales or economic activity tied to the school year or the travel season), the seasonal factors are ***estimates of average weather effects for each month, for example, the average January decrease in new home construction in the Northeastern region of the U.S. due to cold and storms***. Seasonal adjustment does not account for abnormal weather conditions or for year-to-year changes in weather. It is important to note that seasonal factors are estimates based on present and past experience and that future data may show a different pattern of seasonal factors." Q 13: "What is an annual rate? Why are seasonally adjusted data often shown as annual rates?"
" Very generally, what we call the seasonally adjusted annual rate for an individual month (quarter) is an estimate of what the annual total would be if non-seasonal conditions were the same all year. This 'rate' is not a rate in a technical sense but is a ***level estimate***." Q16: "What is an indirect adjustment?  Why is it used? If an aggregate time series is a sum (or other composite) of component series that are seasonally adjusted, then the sum of the adjusted component series provides a seasonal adjustment of the aggregate series that is called the indirect adjustment. This adjustment is usually different from the direct adjustment that is obtained by applying the seasonal adjustment program to the aggregate (or composite) series. When the component series have quite distinct seasonal patterns and have adjustments of good quality, indirect seasonal adjustment is usually of better quality. Indirect seasonal adjustments are preferred by many data users because they are consistent with the adjustments of the component series.
Example: United States Total Housing Starts United States = Northeast Region + Midwest Region + South Region + West Region Because seasonal patterns are different in the different regions of the country, we can estimate the seasonality better by adjusting at the regional level and summing the results to obtain the seasonal adjustment for the U.S. total." (Regional components: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/release/tables?rid=27&eid=20911#snid=20913)
https://web.archive.org/web/20170113192428/http://www.census.gov/const/www/faq2.html United States Census Bureau is frequently doing seasonal adjustments and reports Seasonally adjusted annual rate (SAAR):
" The SAAR is calculated by dividing the unadjusted month rate for the month by its seasonality factor and multiplying by 12 to create an annual rate."

Housing start graphs show a steady increase in housing starts since the 2008 recession save the recent dip from acute problems created by coronavirus.
The conditions underpinning the housing market appear to be 3-fold - unemployment rate, mortgage rates, housing prices.
Unemployment rate is approximately 8% range and by most indications should continue to lower in the next 6 months regardless of outcome of the election. This would provide wage support for housing purchases which should keep demand for housing high.
Mortgage rates are at historic lows and the FED is projecting to maintain interest rates at or near zero into or through 2022. That would provide a low borrowing cost for home purchases and should maintain strong demand for purchases.
A potential negative for the housing market is the near all-time high in median prices nationwide. Multiple factors seem to be contributing to continued demand driven price increases - stimulus payments keeping individuals out of major personal debt, desire to move into larger living arrangements in projection of continued remote working, and extremely lost cost of borrowing. However, there is a limit to the price affordability compared to the wages. If the housing prices reach that price point demand will plateau.
One last consideration might serve as a brake on purchases - mortgage defaults. Current mortgage default rates are falling, however signs show this is being driven more by federal protection through forbearance programs which are due to expire in March 2021.
Current housing starts are just over 1.4 million and I evaluate the combination of factors above should lead to slow and steady rise over the next six months.

Demand should be up, cash sloshing around all over the place, unemployed provide readily available labor, states no longer inhibiting construction due to Covid-19. Fires, floods and storms have reduced existing stock further fueling demand.

Seasonal adjustment appears to be a big problem, as the most recent data in (HOUST) shows big jumps, probably due to the fact that the seasonality inherent to the data does not fit to the actual "additional" seasonality imposed by the pandemic and in its wake the almost nation-wide lock down between March and May; obviously there were numerous permits that could not be transferred into housing contruction ("Housing Starts"). Housing permits used to be higher than actual monthly housing starts by up to 10%, until the recession began in November 2019 and December 2019, which may be the result of uncertainty about the future long-term interest rates, and the FED's future course. Obviously, the risk premium in real estate loans was considered "too high" for most of 2019, so that a significant backlog with real estates development permitted but not started yet built up. Probably market participants were aware of the possibility of lower interest rates and avoided financing their projects at higher financing cost. Now that federal funding (interest) rates are as low as they will probably go, and are set to remain low for a long time, the above mentioned backlog in permits is financed and finally constructed, which leads to significantly higher actual monthly "Housing Starts" from June to August 2020 (the September figures due in early October, I expect,  will be strong, could also be around 135,000 starts, so the annual figures could end up around 1434 (HOUST)/*1352).

https://fred.stlouisfed.org/data/HOUST.txt In the light of this, it is perfectly comprehensible that POTUS already throughout 2019 attacked the FED for raising their federal funding rate and persistently demanded lower interest rates, as the FED's course endangered the economics of the building & construction sector for private homes, and thus the success of "his" economic policy and the soundness of the housing market. However, it is discomforting to see that housing construction requires ever larger monetary stimulus to reach the same output level: as it has almost become insensitive to monetary stimulus (the market may be by and large saturated at the moment), this spells problems, and maybe even a real crisis on the housing market in the medium term.
Looking again at 
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/HOUST
it is clear that there was a clear trend breach already in January 2006: prior business cycles saw an overall flat trend of annual housing starts of 1,400,000 to 1,600,000 p.a.; in the run-up to the "Great Recession" these levels were undershot in July 2007 (1,354,000) for the first time, and fell as low as 478,000 in April 2009.
Trend after January 2008 appears to lie lower, at 1.1mn to 1.2mn housing starts annually for the next ten years. It now seems that, due to political impulse and very advantageous business (i.e.financing) conditions, housing start return to their long-term trend-level, despite all pandemic obstacles: with regards to housing starts (actual annual, not seasonally adjusted, own calculation), the pandemic effect appears to have lowered annual starts temporarily by up to 40,000 units versus trend growth, and was overcome in July 2020 already. Rolling forward these, it appears set they will surpass 1.4mn units before April 2020, barring the political chaos around November 3rd elections and its impact on business climate and expectations. However, there is one caveat: as we are obliged to forecast seasonally adjusted figures for April 2021, the adjustment being made (and probably causing wild jumps next spring again), makes it somewhat unpredictable, until one knows exactly how the St. Louis FED does the adjustments to the raw data (I'll try to find out...). However, since two major natural disasters hit the U.S. this year with above average destruction (wildfires at the West coast, active hurricane season at the Gulf coast (Texas, Louisiana)) and at least 40,000 to 50,000 "structures" (at least that I heard of) were either burned or blown away, there will probably be an increased demand of re-construction in these areas and thus a five-digit number of additional housing starts from this effect alone before April 2021. In addition, from the figures of between January 2019 and August 2020, there's a stock of roughly 96,300 housing permits (PERMITNSA) (2,302,100 permits in total) that probably have not yet transmitted into construction starts (HOUSTNSA) (2,204,800 housing starts) and that may push next year's figures at some point, once construction has begun (if there's a complete catch-up and none of the developments will be abandoned). My best guess for the final outcome: (HOUST) April 2021, published May 2021: 1,435

I tried to think of math-y ways to come up with an outside view for the base rate, but got frustrated. 
Part of my problem is that I'm confused by the fact that the FRED graph seems to be measuring units in "thousands" but the figures given above are given in the millions.  
I decided for now to count the info about wildfires and lumber industry and mortgage rates as "noise," and try to find a base rate.
I looked at the FRED graph for housing starts for the period of 2010-Aug 2020.  The interesting thing was that there's a clear visual pattern:  every year, the line goes up and down in clumps of spikes (wish I could paste in a screenshot but can't).   But in addition to that the overall trend is that the number of housing starts goes gradually up, year on year. 

So even though the housing starts "crashed" in April 2020 relative to the rest of 2020 so far, the April 2020 housing starts are higher than, say, anytime in 2011-2012.   So if the overall trend over a decade is upward, and if the lowpoint of 2020 was April 2020, I'd expect that the point on the graph in 2021 would be mostly above the lowest point in 2020.  So, in other words, April 2021 would probably be a higher housing start rate than the .934 million of April 2020.   Absent figuring out some kind of math model that would give me a more precise prediciton for April 2021, I'll make a guess for a starting forecast that it's a 70% chance the April 2021 rate would be between 1.2 and 1.4 million.
